summary: The text discusses the importance of action over motion, and repetition over perfection, in habit formation. It illustrates this with an anecdote about a photography class divided into two groups: a quantity group, graded on the number of photos produced, and a quality group, graded on the excellence of a single photo. The quantity group, by focusing on taking action and experimenting, produced the best photos. The text contrasts motion (planning, strategizing) with action (behavior that delivers an outcome), noting that motion doesn't produce results and is often used to avoid failure. It emphasizes that mastering a habit requires repetition, not perfection, and that habit formation is a process of becoming more automatic through repetition. Repetition is a form of change, and habits form based on frequency, not time. All habits move from practice to automaticity.

evidence.verbatim_text: [03:03:41,467,03:03:48,271] On the first day of class, Jerry Ullisman, a professor at the University of Florida, divided his film photography students into two groups.
[03:03:49,491,03:03:53,353] Everyone on the left side of the classroom, he explained, would be in the quantity group.
[03:03:53,913,03:03:56,555] They would be graded solely on the amount of work they produced.
[03:04:08,066,03:04:12,347] Meanwhile, everyone on the right side of the classroom would be in the quality group.
[03:04:13,228,03:04:15,629] They would be graded only on the excellence of their work.
[03:04:22,598,03:04:27,844] At the end of the term, he was surprised to find that all of the best photos were produced by the quantity group.

[03:04:28,805,03:04:37,574] During the semester, these students were busy taking photos, experimenting with composition and lighting, testing out various methods in the darkroom, and learning from their mistakes.
[03:04:42,713,03:04:46,475] Meanwhile, the quality group sat around speculating about perfection.
[03:04:47,115,03:04:52,617] In the end, they had little to show for their efforts other than unverified theories and one mediocre photo.
[03:05:29,569,03:05:32,631] When you're in motion, you're planning and strategizing and learning.
[03:05:33,151,03:05:35,893] And those are all good things, but they don't produce a result.
[03:05:37,293,03:05:40,916] Action, on the other hand, is the type of behavior that would deliver an outcome.
[03:06:21,818,03:06:28,260] But more often than not, we do it because motion allows us to feel like we're making progress without running the risk of failure.
[03:07:13,745,03:07:17,828] If you want to master a habit, the key is to start with repetition, not perfection.
[03:07:33,165,03:07:38,866] Habit formation is the process by which a behavior becomes progressively more automatic through repetition.
[03:09:39,403,03:09:45,044] So, both common sense and scientific evidence agree, repetition is actually a form of change.
[03:10:12,053,03:10:19,055] All habits follow a similar trajectory from effortful practice to automatic behavior, a process known as automaticity.
[03:10:44,639,03:10:50,868] These learning curves reveal an important truth about behavior change. Habits form based on frequency, not time.
